page.title: 16FARMING ECONOMY, TRURO AREA.
page.content: Profit margins in farming in this area are small. The owner-occupier, family farmers make sufficient money to live comfortably, not luxuriously, & invest in their farms. Capital is tied up in stock, modern machinery, & buildings; the expense of these is balanced by increased efficiency & reduction in expenditure on employing workers.Costs have risen steadily for several years, while prices for beef & lamb have altered little:a bullock of 500/600kg. liveweight sells for Â£1.86/kg.; a lamb approx. 20kg. deadweight is Â£2.75 in spring, reducing in summer/autumn. A tractor which cost Â£1,000 in 1970 is now Â£15,000. Tractor fuel, a major running cost, is Â£500 for 500 gallons. This area was traditionally dairy,beef & sheep country,but more money can now be made from cereals ("barley-barons") which require considerable investment.
